Article.ArticleTitle: Dry Particulate Nitrate Deposition in China.

AbstractText: A limited number of ground measurements of dry particulate nitrate deposition (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) makes it difficult and challenging to fully know the status of the spatial and temporal variations of dry NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> depositions over China. This study tries to expand the ground measurements of NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> concentrations at monitoring sites to a national scale, based on the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) NO<sub>2</sub> columns, NO<sub>2</sub> profiles from an atmospheric chemistry transport model (Model for Ozone and Related chemical Tracers, version 4, MOZART-4) and monitor-based sources, and then estimates the NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> depositions on a regional scale based on an inferred model. The ground NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations were first derived from NO<sub>2</sub> columns and the NO<sub>2</sub> profiles, and then the ground NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> concentrations were derived from the ground NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations and the relationship between NO<sub>2</sub> and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> based on Chinese Nationwide Nitrogen Deposition Monitoring Network (NNDMN). This estimated dry NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> depositions over China will be helpful in determining the magnitude and pollution status in regions without ground measurements, supporting the construction plan of environmental monitoring in future.
